Register for the Live Online Webinar


Organizations are striving to become more agile and move to the cloud, as they develop cutting-edge enterprise applications for today’s market. As enterprise development teams increasingly choose open source databases to leverage proven cloud-scale solutions, they also find that no single database can meet their needs and are therefore adopting a multi- database strategy. This situation presents enterprises with challenges as they struggle to support new data technologies in production while reducing costs and managing risk. 

 
IBM® Compose Enterprise delivers an IBM-managed cloud data platform through IBM Bluemix® Dedicated, SoftLayer or Amazon Web Services, enabling your organization to run a wide variety of open source, databases: mongoDB, Redis, elasticsearch, PostgreSQL, RethinkDB, RabbitMQ, and etcd. During this webinar, we will look closely at Compose, and explore the different databases and managed services. 

Speaker Bio:
Saswata Sengupta is an Open Source Technical Evangelist for IBM Big data and Analytics group, with expertise in data science/engineering, Spark, Big Insights, Hadoop, IBM Data Science and Watson Cognitive solutions. He has over 16+ years of experience in the technology industry and more than 4 years working with Big Data Technologies like Hadoop, Hive, Spark, Storm, Kafka and Elastic Search. Saswata holds a Masters from University of Wales and enjoys reading, hiking and crossfit.
column17: Managed Platform for Multiple Open Source Databases Webinar

Register for Live Online Webinar


Machine learning, which is commonly defined as the method of allowing computers to learn without being explicitly programmed, is enabling systems to learn, reason and engage with us in a more natural and personalized way. These systems get smarter and more customized through interactions with data, devices and people. Apache Spark’s machine learning (ML) library, makes practical machine learning scalable and easy. In this session, we will introduce machine learning concepts, overview Spark’s ML capabilities, discuss approaches to building systems to make product recommendations to consumers, and walk step by step through a demo showing how to build a movie recommendation system using Spark ML.
column17: Building a Recommendation Engine for Movies with Spark ML - Webinar

Register to Live Webinar


Big Replicate is the world’s only wide area network active transactional replication technology that delivers continuous availability, streaming backup, uninterrupted migration, hybrid cloud and burst-to-cloud, exceeding the most demanding enterprise SLAs across any combination of Hadoop distributions and cloud storage.

In this webinar, the speaker will showcase Active-Active replication at two data centers using “Big Replicate” technology. Along with the demo, the speaker will discuss replication use cases in Hadoop.

Speaker Bio: 

Gautam Siwach is a Technical Evangelist at IBM in their Open Source Analytics team. Gautam has many years of experience in Big Data Solution Architecture and Data Analysis with organizations Accenture, Aetna and JPMC. He is the author of papers in the field of Big Data and Computer Security Algorithms.

This webinar will cover an overview of Watson Data Platform capabilities and how to empower users across the organization to make the most out of their data. What if you can shorten the time it takes to create value out of your existing organizational data ? 

What if you can provision a common analytic engine with managed services that will enable you to embrace multiple cloud platforms ? IBM Watson Data Platform is the first cloud-based data and analytics platform to support cognitive businesses. It enables access, collaboration and paths to insights by connecting all users through trusted access to a variety of data, discovering new possibilities and opportunities with built-in intelligence, automation and machine learning and accelerating outcomes with rapid deployment of new data models and fast embedding of insights into processes, applications and services. 

Let us show you how Watson Data Platform can be the milestone of your organization analytics strategy and empower your organization into the new Cognitive analytics era.

Streaming analytics and Internet Of Things ( IOT) are gaining momentum in the data and analytics industry. Apache Spark established itself as a leader in fast data processing with its ease of use. With its single execution engine and unified programming model for batch and streaming workloads, it stands out from other distributed stream processing engines. 

Join this webinar to go over basics and internals of the Streaming module of Apache Spark along with code samples. This topic is intended for audiences with some familiarity or working experience with Apache Spark core.​ 


Apache Spark Streaming:​ 


Architecture and Execution Model 

Spark Streaming I/O 

Programing model and Streaming Operations (api) 

Fault tolerance and reliability 

Performance Considerations 


Presenter Bio: 


Suresh Matlapudi is an Open Source Analytics Solution Engineer with IBM. He is a hands-on Engineer with deep experience in distributed data processing, Big Data, Data Warehousing and Hybrid Information Architectures. His current work involves supporting sales teams with pre-sales and technical specifications for Open Source Analytics tools, specifically Hadoop/Spark and execution of several outreach programs to support Open Source adoption by Analytics teams. 

Before joining IBM he was involved in building some of the large-scale data processing systems at companies like eHarmony, Deem, American Express, Knights Bridge Solutions.

Big SQL is a value added service on Big Insights - Big SQL enables users to query Hive and HBase data using ANSI compliant SQL. While Hadoop is highly scalable, Big SQL’s advanced cost-based optimizer and Massively Parallel Processing (MPP) architecture, can run queries smarter, not harder, supporting more concurrent users and more complex SQL with less hardware compared to other SQL solutions for Hadoop.

Speaker Bio : Gautam Siwach is a Technical Evangelist at IBM, US in their Open Source Analytic division. Gautam has many years of experience as Chair for Big Data technology conference, Big Data - Subject Matter Expert, and Solution Architect for Data Analysis with organizations like Ryerson, Accenture, Aetna and JPMC. He is the author of papers and journals in the field of Big Data and Computer Security Algorithms for IEEE (US/Canada), ASEE (America), TCN (UK), and holds first class MS degree in Computer Science, Studied at PENNSTATE, YALE, MIT, and UNH. Gautam Siwach is a recognized portfolio advocate by IBM, Software specialist by Microsoft, Licensed Programmer from SUN,Oracle.
column17: Big SQL, Powerful Query engine on Hadoop

column3: Structured Streaming is a new scalable and fault-tolerant stream processing engine built on the Spark SQL engine. Structured Streaming allows you to express your streaming computation the same way you would express a computation on static data. This has two benefits. The first is code reuse as essentially the same queries be run on batch, interactive or streaming data. Second, it simplifies streaming application development as you can operate on streams of data just like you can on static data using DataFrames. Structured Streaming abstracts away the complexity of streaming analytics allowing you to perform streaming analytics without having to reason about streaming. The Spark SQL engine takes care of running Structured Streaming queries and incrementally and continuously updating the result as streaming data continues to arrive. With Spark Structured Streaming, you can express streaming aggregations, event-time windows, as well as join streaming data to static data. In this session, we’ll walk through the basics of Structured Streaming, its programming model and APIs. The concepts will be illustrated using code examples. Then, we’ll walk through a demo of analyzing both static and streaming sensor data to show how the same queries can be used on each, thereby simplifying streaming analytics application development, and how static and streaming data can be leveraged together.
column17: Introduction to Spark Structured Streaming

column3:
This is a live webinar. Please register at:

http://bit.ly/2lnJJYe. Join IBM for a deep dive into how to build a cross-industry, scalable streaming pipeline with machine learning using Apache Spark and Apache Kafka! We will connect to a dynamic, real time data source from Wikipedia, ingest it into Kafka and pipe it through to Spark Streaming. There we showcase the power and simplicity of the Spark API with Spark Core, SparkSQL, DataFrames, and SparkMLlib. Finally, we'll write the results of our predictions out to PostgreSQL. Intended audience: Data scientists, data engineers, big data developers.
column17: Generalized Streaming Pipelines with Spark Streaming, Kafka

Description:
IBM Bluemix provides multitude of services in the cloud. One such service is the 'Insights from Twitter', which provides sentiment and other enrichments for tweets.

The IBM Data Science Experience is an interactive, collaborative, cloud-based environment where data scientists can use various tools to retrieve insights. In this session, using keywords and tags for a movie we will retrieve the daily sentiments through the 'Insights from Twitter' service, combine it with actual daily movie collections to create a simple model. This model can then be used for predicting collections for related movies and sequels. Please attend and see how all this can be achieved easily by leveraging SparkSQL and Python along with machine learning.

As enterprise adoption of Hadoop increases, the challenges associated with moving Hadoop from experiments or lab to actual mission critical production environment have also been prevalent. Challenges such as data availability and consistency across the Hadoop clusters, commercial data warehouse/sources and locations as well as regulatory data protection concerns create major hindrance to mission critical use. This session will cover how IBM BigReplicate helps you overcome these challenges and ensure you unleash the most value out of your Hadoop deployments whether on cloud and/or on-premise. Speaker:
Kevin Wang is a senior Big Data support engineer and evangelist who is passionate about partnering with companies big and small to unlock the most value out of their IBM Big Data solutions such as IBM BigInsights, IBM Open Platform and IBM BigReplicate.

Unsupervised machine learning helps to show you patterns in your data without any predefined labels. Using Reddit comments, we can apply a term frequency - inverse document frequency statistic to each comment among a group, and cluster them by keywords using SparkML. With these clusters, we can then discover personality insights using one of IBM Watson API’s.

Join us to learn how to leverage the power of Apache Spark through SparkML, and one of Watson Cognitive APIs: Personality Insights.

Streams V3.2 includes new features and functions designed to instantly analyze and fuse massive volumes of data and integrates with existing infrastructures. It delivers new capabilities to improve usability, support enterprise readiness, and streamline enterprise integration.

Description

BigData represents a new and fast growing era in data exploration and utilization. These course materials cover Hadoop fundamentals. Hadoop is an open-source implementation of frameworks for reliable, scalable, distributed computing and data storage which can be used for managing Big Data. Course modules cover Hadoop architecture, HDFS, MapReduce, Querying Data (Pig, Hive, JAQL) and Moving Data (Flume). Hands-on labs, using IBM BigInsights, are included in the course. BigInsights, which is based on Hadoop, is available as a virtual image. The course is approximately 8 hours of course content, including time for the labs.

Note: This is a WebCast only since we want that everybody benefits from the opportunity that Chris is in Europe.

Christopher Bienko is WW expert on Data Management in the Cloud and everybody will have the chance to ask questions in this session.


Technical deep-dives will follow this session.

Cloudant is based on Apache CouchDB but enhanced in serveral ways.

Cloudant is an innovator in data management, providing a NoSQL, JSON database-as-a-service (DBaaS) that enables developers of fast-growing Web and mobile applications to focus on developing their applications without the need to manage database infrastructure or growth. In this one hour introduction to Cloundant, we'll examine how Cloudant accelerates and extends IBM’s Big Data & Analytics portfolio. The agenda includes a review of the NoSQL database landscape, as well as specific features, use cases, and Cloudant customer success stories. Come and equip yourself with an understanding of this disruptive new technology for the world of databases.

Summary:

Learn how real-time processing of structured, semi-structured and unstructured data is done using a modern streaming engine (in this case IBM InfoSphere Streams) but the concepts you will learn are also applicable to Apache Storm or Spark Streaming

Highlights:

- Data at Rest vs. Data in Motion


- Operations on Streams, Windowing, Punctuations


- Sort, Filter, Aggregate, Merge, Join, Spit Data


- Extend Engine with Java Operators


- Extend Engine with C/C++ Operators

Description:

This course is designed to teach you about the Streams Processing Language. It will begin with the basic concepts of InfoSphere Streams and the basic Streams Processing Language operators used in a Streams program. You will learn how to access data from an external source using the Source type operators and write an output stream using the Sink type operators. You will then learn how and when to use the various Stream operators, like the Functor, Punctor, Aggregation, Sort, Join, Split, Barrier, Delay, and Switch operators. Lab exercise demonstrations will use the InfoSphere Streams IDE that is based upon Eclipse as the development and testing environment, but you will get the opportunity to see the invocation of the compilation of a Streams program from the command line as well.

column3:
# Scale-up vs. Scale-out, how massive parallel multicore systems are shaping the BigData ecosystem

Hadoop workloads today rely on commodity x86 infrastructure, which although having cheaper costs, also provide lower reliability than UNIX Servers. IBM, through its proprietary POWER Architecture, wants to provide an alternative, aimed at achieving a higher performance at comparable prices. We will discuss IBM's Hadoop Reference Architecture, its performance, and the technical features of the POWER Chip, that enable Hadoop workloads to run faster, and achieve higher throughput per core.

# On-Premise vs. Cloud: Free or highly competitive (BigData) data management solutions in the cloud: Column Stores, Document Stores, Hadoop

- Brief Introduction to MongoDB incl. Live - Demo

- Brief Introduction to CouchDB incl. Live - Demo of Cloudant - App deployed to Bluemix

- Intro to DB2 and DB2 BLU vectorized column processing

- Intro to MySQL as a Service

- Intro to PostgreSQL as a Service

- Intro to Cloudera as a Service

- Intro to Cassandra as a Service

CALLING ALL DEVELOPERS .... JOIN THE BIG DATA FOR SOCIAL GOOD CHALLENGE

Big data exists in just about everything we use and do. It comes from phones, cars, roads, power lines, waterways, food crates, and innumerable other items you’d never think of as computers. This data speaks volumes about our collective behavior and society – so let’s use it to do something incredible! IBM invites developers and data enthusiasts to take a deep dive into real world civic issues using big data and the IBM Bluemix Analytics for Hadoop service. Analyze one of our curated datasets or bring your own (provided it meets these requirements)! Use Hadoop and your data to create a clickable and interactive data visualization to highlight insights that you’ve found.

Ready to get started? $40,000 in prizes will be awarded....

Register here:http://ibmhadoop.challengepost.com/

What to Create: Participants must create a working, clickable, and interactive data visualization utilizing the Analytics for Hadoop service on IBM Bluemix.

Data Requirements: Your data visualization must analyze one or more datasets included in the curated list of datasets on the Data page OR meet the data size, content, and licensing requirements described on the Data page. The total size of the Datasets analyzed must be between 500MB - 7GB in size.

Check out the requirements then go get your IBM Bluemix extended promo code and check out the datasets!

The POWER Architecture has been for many years the leader in the Unix Market, thanks for its high performance and capabilities in terms of reliability and security. Today, IBM is bringing this platform closer to the Open Source world, making it available at commodity prices for Linux-based Software. Partnering with Google and other prime IT players like Nvidia, Tyan and Mellanox, IBM is also fostering a community-based ecosystem based on Open Stack called the Open Power Foundation, where the Platform capabilities can be extended to create custom-tailored hardware and benefit the Software even more.

Come and discover:
- What are the technical features of the POWER Platform that can benefit your software
- Get to know other Software vendors that are already making use of the advanced capabilities of POWER
- Try our your Linux-based Application on a Linux on POWER server

The event will be held in German

THIS IS A WEB CONFERENCE ONLY.  TIME OF WEB CONFERENCE LOCALLY IS BASED ON LIVE-STREAM START - PACIFIC DAYLIGHT TIME. DETAILS TO CONNECT TO LIVE-STREAM ARE INDICATED BELOW. 

Apache Spark is an open source processing engine built around speed, ease of use, and analytics. If you have large amounts of data that requires low latency processing that a typical Map Reduce program cannot provide, Spark is the alternative.

Spark performs at speeds up to 100 times faster than Map Reduce for iterative algorithms or interactive data mining. Spark provides in-memory cluster computing for lightning fast speed and supports Java, Scala, and Python APIs for ease of development. Spark allows data scientists to build models quickly and supports iterative jobs on distributed datasets. This means more people can apply deep intelligence into applications to make everything smarter, including the Internet of Things (IoT), machine learning, web, mobile, social, business process and more. 

Do you believe in the value of Spark, in the speed, efficiency and flexibility of this in-memory compute engine? IBM does.  Emphatically.That's why we're committed to do everything we can to accelerate the adoption of Spark for enterprise analytics, where Spark promises seemingly unlimited value.

On June 15, 2015, IBM will host a Spark Community event in San Francisco, California: IBM | Spark - The Start of Something Big in Data and Design. There will be a live demo showcase, refreshments, and a Town Hall discussion featuring some of the most trail-blazing data scientists in today's Spark Community, including:

•  Edd Dumbill, VP Strategy, Silicon Valley Data Science
•  Mike Tamir, Chief Science Officer & VP of Data Science & Education at Galvanize
•   Fernando Perez, Staff Scientist at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory & Founding Investigator of the Berkeley Institute for Data Science
•   Haoyuan Li, CEO and Founder of Tachyon Nexus
•   Shankar Venkataraman, Distinguished Engineer & CTO, IBM Analytics Platform at IBM
•   Paco Nathan, Director, Community Evangelism, Databricks

Spark Community members will also deliver 5-minute lightning talks to describe exciting projects they're working on.

We will provide a livestream presentation of what these Spark leaders have to say.

Live Streaming Link:

To get additional details about Spark you can sign up now for a reminder at:

http://www.ibm.com/analytics/us/en/technology/spark/

Scroll down to "Can't attend in Person"?  Sign up for a reminder and add it to your calendar.

Additional information on Spark:

http://bigdatauniversity.com/bdu-wp/bdu-course/spark-fundamentals/

Link to Spark Technology Information

http://www.ibm.com/analytics/us/en/technology/spark/

Happy Sparking.

column3:
6-6:30 PM Keynote: "Data Storage Futures"

How is data storage evolving? Which new media can we expect soon?
Will disks still be around in 10 years? Is there a limit to Moore's law?

Dr. Axel Koester, Chief Technologist, IBM EMEA Storage Competence Center Mainz

6:30-6:50 PM Real time video analytics with InfoSphere Streams, OpenCV and R (live demo) and real life experiences with streaming analytics

Unstructured data are a fast growing area and a source for many innovative Big Data & Analytics solutions. Often the first idea of unstructured data seems to be that it's probably text data, even though that is just a small part. A lot of that "new data" is sensor data and especially multimedia (audio, video). Even though this part is growing extremely fast, it is very rarely used in analytics today. And even less in a real time context.

I will demonstrate what does it mean to work with this new data in real time on a live demo and explain important concepts & implementation approaches. The demo shows a drill equipment as it is used to build tunnels and how to analyze the output on the conveyor belt visually with machine learning approaches. Beside this, I will talk about some recent projects in the area of real time analytics where streaming analytics is already used in a big data context.

Stephan Reimann, Senior IT Specialist Information Management, IBM  München

6:50 PM -7:15 PM DOCKER: Introduction & Demo, Mirko Stocker, Hochschule Rapperswil, HSR

7:15-7:40 PM Live coding session: And end to end Twitter Evolving topic dashboard using NodeRED, Node.js, Hadoop, BigSQL (Hive), PlayFramework/Scala/Cloudfoundry, JQuery, Romeo Kienzler, IBM

7:40-8:00 PM Distributed Machine Learning: Classification and Regression on a Large Scale, Martin Jaggi, ETH Zurich

8:00 - 8:20 PM Introduction to Bitcoin, Olaf Klein, IBM

column3:
Date: Wednesday, 9 December 2015, 14:00 – 16:00
Place: Seminar room C159, Institute of cell biology, Baltzerstrasse 4, 3012 Bern
Speaker: Romeo Kienzler, Chief Data Scientist - IBM Cloud Transformation Lab Zurich Abstract:

Container based virtualization is the new hype coming from Silicon Valley 2015. The buzzword behind this is DOCKER. Although present for many years in cgroups, namespaces and LXC - container based virtualzation really took off as Docker Inc. brought this technology to the masses. Today, every 2nd IT startup is running on DOCKER. Enterprises and Academic institutions are slowly adapting as well. In this session we will learn what DOCKER really is, what Linux Kernel extensions are used and how you can use it in your environment. We will create a DOCKER image from scratch, add persistent storage to it and showcase a little cluster computing task using ApacheFlink and DOCKER-Compose. Finally I'll give you a short introduction to DOCKER on the cloud - currently offered by nearly every cloud service provider - and exemplified in the IBM Bluemix Platform Cloud.

Note: If available please bring your own laptop to the seminar.
column17: Introduction to Docker
column33: Institute of cell biology, Seminar room C159

Trifork, Basho and IBM Softlayer invite you to this Strategy&Tech Talk:  From Meters to Pacemakers - the Plumbing to turn IoT hype into reality. 


This Evening we will present you with three sessions all dealing with how you can get the most out of IoT and your Big Data: 

The session with Basho Technologies:
The Managing Director of Basho EMEA - Manu Marchal will give you his insight into the prospects and the opportunities and how Riak TS can solve your Big Data problems.

The world is currently creating over 2.5 quintillion bits of data every day.  This data, generated by mobile devices, apps, sensors and wearable tech represents highly valuable information.  Making accurate, real-time decisions with raw data to unlock its economic potential is now becoming crucial for countless businesses. Many organizations are still struggling to find out how to leverage the promise of big data.

In this session you will: 

explore the technological challenges of big datafind the right infrastructure for your big data workloadsdiscover how to overcome the common pitfalls when using Cloud and NoSQL databases 

Mining raw data can be gold to your business. Find out how you can exploit its value.

The session with IBM SoftLayer: 
John Easton, IBM Distinguished Engineer and Lead Cloud Advisor UKI and Nordics, will be the voice of IBM Cloud SoftLayer and his talk will cover: 

We find ourselves in a data-rich world;  having easy access to data from a multitude of different sources.  Only a few years ago, very few companies could do this.  Now everyone has the potential to exploit data from sources as varied as weather, sensor, social etc.  Organisations relying on traditional data processing techniques will be unable to keep up, let alone take advantage of the new opportunities this opens up.  A new approach is needed:  one based around cloud and cognitive techniques.  This session will use a variety of real client examples to show the art of the possible.  To demonstrate how organisations bring these different data sources together and apply innovative analytical approaches using cloud platforms optimised for these problems to disrupt industries and create new business value.

John Easton will give you his insights on the following:  examples of IoT application in real world, from premature infants treatment, to energy and utilities industry (bridging the Weather Company story Manu from Basho will use), to transport  why and what type of compute and network infrastructure is critical for those type of workloads, showcasing the readiness and the uniqueness of IBM Cloud SoftLayer with single tenant environment and robust low latency network NodeRED from Bluemix, that provides a browser-based flow editor that makes it easy to wire together devices, APIs, and online services by using the wide range of nodes in the palette cognitive computing with Watson awe-inspiring videos presenting application of all the presented technologies in production  

The session with IBM Innovation: 
IBM Innovation will be joining this talk with a session on “IoT Sensor outlier detection in the cloud using dashDB and R”

Romeo Kienzler, Data Scientist at IBM InnovationCenter will explore how to create predictive models for real-time IoT data analysis: 


'IoT mainly is seen as distributed data generation. In order to create valuable insights this data has to be stored for retrospective analysis to create predictive models for real-time analysis. In this talk we show how to stream mqtt data acquired through subscription to IoT sensors into a distributed relational database and how the IBM R accelerator is used to push down R code to SQL and stored procedures to react in real-time to changing sensor data'
column17: Strategy & Tech Talk - From meters to pacemakers - the Internet of Things

Event Agenda

18:30 - 19:00

Arrival and socializing

19:00 - 20:00

Michal Okoniewski, Scientific IT Services, ETH Zürich

"ADAM standard and other ways of scalable cloud-processing of genomic big data with Spark"

Next generation sequencing (NGS) technology has become a serious computational challenge since its commercial introduction in 2008. Currently, thousands of machines worldwide produce daily billions of sequenced nucleotide base pairs of data. Due to continuous development of faster and economical sequencing technologies, processing the large amounts of data produced by high throughput sequencing technologies became the main challenge in bioinformatics. It can be solved by the new generation of software tools based on the paradigms and principles developed within the Hadoop ecosystem. This talk presents the overall perspective for data analysis software for genomics and prospects for the emerging applications with a particular emphasis on the ADAM standard.

The presentation will include an introduction to analysing the genomic big data in a scalable form with ADAM. It will also include examples of using Spark, SparkR and Parquet that can be more generic in the data science.
column17: ADAM standard - processing of genomic big data with ApacheSpark

Bio:

1. Rajesh K Jeyapaul is a Cloud Solution Architect from IBM EcoSystem & Developer (ECoD) organization , focusing on enabling partners and developers on IBM cloud solution especially on Bluemix , IoT , Mobility and Big Data.

He started his carrier on Avionics real time simulation as a Research Fellow in India’s Defense organization. Further joining IBM , he has worked on various technologies involving java virtual machine, operating system , virtualization and cloud OS management.

He has co-authored books on virtualization and cloud system management. He loves to spend time with his family and play violin during his leisure time

2. Romeo Kienzler is a Chief Data Scientist at the IBM Watson IoT Division. In his role he is involved in international Data Mining and Data Science projects to ensure that clients get the maximum out of their data. He works as Associate Professor for Data Mining at a Swiss University and his current research focus is on Cloud Scale Data Mining using Open Source Technologies including R, ApacheSpark, SystemML, ApacheFlink and DeepLearning4J. He also contributes to various open source projects.

BerlinTOA LiveStream: DeepLearning and Advanced Machine Learning on IoT

Since the 150 available seats on Berlin seem to be booked out (http://www.eventbrite.com/e/deeplearning-and-advanced-machine-learning-on-iot-tickets-26145758668) we decided to stream the talk, so if you are interested feel free to join via live stream:

http://www.youtube.com/c/RomeoKienzler/live

Abstract:
Currently DeepLearning - large neural networks with advanced topologies - are taking over the machine learning ecosystem. In the case of times series they currently are superseding Hidden Markov models and other traditional algorithms. In this talk we will show how Deep Neural Networks can be used for anomaly detection on high dimensional network monitoring data. Do it yourself and read accelerometer data from your mobile device and stream this data to via MQTT to the Watson IoT Platform. Learn how to classify this data into different movement patterns (standing/sitting, walking, running, dancing).
column17: BerlinTOA LiveStream: DeepLearning and Advanced Machine Learning on IoT

column3: Webcast on Youtube: http://www.youtube.com/c/RomeoKienzler/live
column17: Webcast@SDS: CrashCourse on DeepLearning4J on top of Spark (Romeo Kienzler, IBM)

column3:
Webcast MipTec Basel: Massive parallel GPU accelerated DeepLearning in the cloud

http://www.youtube.com/c/RomeoKienzler/live

DeepLearning (DL) is currently taking off in various AI (Artificial Intelligence) domains like Image Recognition, NLP (Natural Language Processing) and Speech Recognition. But it also already entered the Life Science domain. Recently researchers from the University of Toronto implemented a DL Network able to predict Alternative Splicing (AS) patterns in individual tissues and differences in splicing patterns across tissues using a model inferred from mouse RNA-Seq data whereas Atomwise, a Silicon Valley based startup evaluates 8.2 million compounds on a IBM Blue Gene/Q supercomputer. GPUs are the key accelerator on DL - that´s why "In Silico Medicine" - a startup founded in Baltimore is closely partnering with NVIDIA. DL is at the early stages of development but in this talk we want to motivate machine learning experts to apply these algorithms on their problems and actively contributing to this emerging topic in AI research by providing a Open Source based framework for running massive parallel DL computations on GPU clusters in the Cloud by running DeepLearning4J, ND4J and jcuBLAS on top of ApacheSpark. First, we will introduce the overall architecture, followed by a live demonstration of the system and we end with a call for action to use and contribute to the framework.

http://www.youtube.com/c/RomeoKienzler/live
column17: Webcast MipTec Basel: Massive parallel GPU accelerated DeepLearning in the cloud

column3:
IBM values our community of clients and business partners. Each year, we support and build our community by working closely with IBM advocates and helping them to become 

IBM Champions

IBM Champions are a select group of external advocates made up of clients, business partners and independent consultants who make exceptional contributions to the technical community by speaking at conferences, running or actively participating in user groups, evangelizing relevant technical topics via social media, and helping our clients make the most of IBM technology. 

We are looking for clients and business partners to join the program and are looking for applications in the areas of data science, data engineering, application development, and business analytics.

Nominations are due by Monday, November 28, 2016

The Champion program is open to candidates worldwide, and candidates may self-nominate or be nominated by someone else. IBM employees are not eligible for the program.  Some benefits of the IBM Champion program: 
- IBM Champions advocate IBM offerings in the community with competence and credibility (content, blogs, presentations, customer references, analyst/press, videos/podcasts, etc.)
- IBM Champions share knowledge with and provide support to the IBM user community (books, articles, blogs, forums, presentations, education, beta programs and customer advisory councils etc.)
- IBM Champions support IBM as brand ambassadors who build awareness, share product knowledge, and provide product feedback as users and beta testers

Read this  blog post  for full IBM Champion program criteria, guidelines and the <a>nomination form</a>.

To learn more about the IBM Champion program from current Champions and Worldwide IBM Champion coordinator Libby Ingrassia, listen to this webcast. Be sure to share the blog and webcast with clients and colleagues who would make great IBM Champions.

Again I'd like to invite you to a group event of one of our peers:

https://www.meetup.com/swiss-big-data/events/236020110/

Agenda

18:00 Welcome & Intro

18:10
Title: Data Science and Data Products at Neue Zürcher Zeitung

Abstract:
With 236 years of age, Neue Zürcher Zeitung (NZZ) is one of the oldest still published newspapers in the world. However, despite its age, NZZ is far from being old-fashioned. Especially when it comes to data-driven decision making and data-driven innovation, NZZ has been investing a lot within the last three years. For wrangling large amounts of data we have been using Apache Spark for almost a year now – and do not regret this choice. It had not only given us flexibility with ad-hoc analytics, but also drives our data-products (in production). In this talk I will share some of our use cases as well as insights we gained over the last year with Apache Spark. I will especially talk about how we calculate article recommendations and showcase some new exciting data products which are currently in active development. 

Bio: 
René Pfitzner is the Lead Data Scientist at NZZ, Switzerland’s newspaper of records. He is interested in media innovation, especially algorithmic approaches for news media. Before joining NZZ he has been a research assistant at ETH Zurich, where his research broadly evolved around the topics “network theory” and “information networks”.

18:50 tba

The demand for machine learning is booming! 

Calling all IT executives, data scientists, Chief Data Officers, data architects and other data geeks.  Join us on February 15th from 2:00-5:30 pm ET via livestream  (replay available starting February 16th) , and discover how machine learning is fundamentally changing the way we work and live.  Hear about cognitive applications that anticipate behavior and learn from data without being explicitly programmed.

You'll learn about the latest breakthrough developments on machine learning as well as Spark, data and analytics. Mike Gualtieri, Vice President and Principal Analyst, Forrester, will present his view on how to best leverage technologies such as big data, predictive analytics, Hadoop/Spark, machine learning, data science, and AI.  Rob Thomas, General Manager, IBM Analytics will host an agenda which will include guest speakers and cover the following topics:

•  Machine Learning Overview

•  Top Trends in Machine Learning & Cognitive Applications

•  Cognitive Analytics and Machine Learning for the Enterprise

•  Live Product Demonstration & Client Roundtable on Machine Learning

•  Data Innovation with Hybrid Transaction/Analytical Processing

•  Spark & Machine Learning for Enterprise Systems

For additional details and to REGISTER, please visit MACHINE LEARNING.

Register NOW and we'll send you a reminder!

A todas y todos

Ya hemos definido el Menú para el primer banquete de sabiduría BigData Hadoop/Spark, con CUOTA DE RECUPERACION


Empezaremos con un Menú a 3 tiempos.

Un primer tiempo de ENTRADA/ENSALADA para degustar el ambiente de almacenamiento distribuido y tolerante a fallas, Hadoop HDFS y sus diferentes aspectos como subir, extraer, cambiar talla bloque, cambiar factor de replicación y acceso a monitoreo por web

Un segundo tiempo con el primer PLATO FUERTE para paladear el ambiente de procesamiento distribuido y tolerante a fallas Apache Spark y sus variados aspectos como creación de un Resient Distributed DataSet (RDD), generacion de DataFrames, y almacenamiento en formato Apache Parquet, para después realizar TRANSFORMACIONES y ACCIONES en los conjuntos de datos. Enseguida se ejecutaran enunciados en un ambiente Spark SQL para crear aplicaciones productivas.

Un tercer tiempo con el segundo PLATO FUERTE para saborear el ambiente en la nuble de  computo distribuido y tolerante a fallas MICROSOFT AZURE y sus diversos aspectos para la generación de aplicaciones en la nube de Aprendizaje automatizado (Machine Learning)

Reserven su mesa, el banquete sera de las 10 am a las 7 pm con una hora para comida, el dia jueves 19 de enero 2017 en nuestras instalaciones a una cuadra del metro Insurgentes, tiene una CUOTA DE RECUPERACION.


Los meseros, cocineros, capitán y cajeros ya están esperándoles

Reservaciones por medio del servidor gmail.com al correo del usuario saxsa2000

Los esperamos numerosos y no se les olvide traer una máquina con al menos Intel I5 y RAM 8Gb para que se lleven a casa su itacate "UNA MAQUINA VIRTUAL CON TODO INSTALADO"

column3:
BigData Science Day, Conferencia Gratuita BigData Analytics Spark, MS Azure y Matemáticas

Viernes 10 de febrero de 2017

Auditorio Carlos Graef en Edificio Amoxcalli

Facultad de Ciencias, Ciudad Universitaria UNAM

Temario

Big Data y aplicaciones con algoritmos matemáticos de la Ciencia de Grandes Volúmenes de Datos (BigData Science)

Con demostraciones de:

Sistema de recomendación con Alternating Least Squares (ALS) y Singular Value Descomposition (SVD).

Microsoft Azure Machine Learning Studio y Microsoft Azure HDInsight

Hoy como se preguntan los “altos dirigentes” en momentos de CRISIS:

¿Y TU QUE HARIAS?

Yo me armaría de CONOCIMIENTO, que es la HERRAMIENTA MÁGICA que permite a los seres humanos describir, entender, modelar y tal vez resolver su problemática.

Hoy el NUEVO PETROLEO son los MILES DE MILLONES DE DATOS que genera la humanidad.

Entonces ¿por qué no PONER MILES DE REFINERIAS para procesar el PETROLEO CRUDO en productos?

Es decir, ¿por qué no PONER MILES DE CENTROS DE CONOCIMIENTO para PROCESAR DATOS CRUDOS en productos, servicios y recursos humanos en CIENCIA DE DATOS?

No se quede fuera de ¿CÓMO CONSTRUIR SU REFINERIA DE DATOS y aprenda las nuevas herramientas para realizar todo con BigData Analytics con herramientas de código abierto como Apache Spark y/o de productos comerciales como Microsoft Azure y Oracle BigData Discovery.

Si quiere ser de la ELITE DEL MUNDO PETROLERO, …, aprenda a TRANSFORMAR EL PETROLEO en VALOR

Si quiere estar preparado para la CRISIS, conviértase en CIENTIFICO DE DATOS

Solo consulte la OFERTA DE EMPLEOS a nivel mundial que SE BUSCA CIENTIFICO DE DATOS!!

Why "Data Scientist" Is The Best Job To Pursue In 2016

Todos aquellos que quieran aportar algo, QUE SE SUBAN A LA CARRETA!!

Hoy creo que debemos empezar a construir los cimientos de LAS REFINERIAS DE DATOS, y crear una CULTURA DEL DESARROLLO basado en el conocimiento.

Empecemos por la Ciencia de Datos, que esto HOY y tal vez durante la próxima década GENERARÁ EMPLEOS.

Nosotros en saXsa, desde hace varios años creemos firmemente en la CANTERA de jóvenes talentos, solo hay que mostrarles el camino y ofrecerles un TERRENO para practicar.

Así en vez de regresarnos a nuestros paisanos los vecinos del norte, vendrán a buscar a los mexican MESI's, Hugo SANCHEZ's, Hector Garcia-Molina, Tessy Lopez Goerne, Mario Molina y tantos talentos!!!

Los esperamos de 12 a 14.30 en la Facultad de Ciencias de la UNAM, Auditorio Amoxcalli para compartirles nuestro gusto por programar en Spark y crear aplicaciones de BigData Analytics y asi convertirse en Científico de Datos

Unanse a nuestro grupo de reuniones (meetup)

https://www.meetup.com/es/saxsaBigDataMexico/

Hoy con la plataforma de computo distribuido y tolerante a fallas Spark, y los lenguajes de programacion Python y Scala con todas sus bibliotecas de soporte al Aprendizaje Automatizado (Machine Learning), sus mecanismos de manejo de torrentes de datos (Spark Streaming) y su soporte para enunciados SQL (Spark SQL) y las bibliotecas graficas como Bokeh de Python, TENEMOS TODO para la construccion de GRANDES REFINERIAS DE DATOS

Microsoft Azure Machine Learning Studio y Microsoft Azure HDInsight

¿Por qué los Sistemas de Recomendación?

En esta era de la tecnologías de la información, las personas utilizan una variedad de estrategias para tomar decisiones en aspectos como ¿qué comprar?, ¿cómo pasar su tiempo libre?, e incluso ¿con quiénes hacer amistad como en las redes sociales?.

Los sistemas de recomendación permiten automatizar algunas de estas estrategias de selección con el objetivo de proporcionar recomendaciones asequibles, personales y de alta calidad.

Cada día, estamos inundados de alternativas y opciones. ¿Qué ponerse? ¿Qué película alquilar en los servicios de renta? ¿Qué productos comprar?

Históricamente, las personas se han basado en las recomendaciones y menciones
de sus compañeros o el asesoramiento de expertos, para apoyar las decisiones y descubrir el nuevo artículo o material a adquirir.

Los sistemas interactivos de Internet ofrecen la oportunidad de ampliar el conjunto de personas de donde se pueden obtener datos para construir sistemas de recomendaciones. Cada acción que se realiza en el sistema, genera un registro y estos sistemas nos permitirán conocer la historia de los usuarios y determinar las preferencias por patrones de comportamiento, que ni ellos ni sus conocidos identifican, lo que puede proporcionar una más afinada experiencia de la selección.

La tecnología de los sistemas de recomendación esta ofreciendo soluciones en ámbitos tan diversos como los productos financieros, bienes raíces, productos electrónicos de consumo, películas, libros, música, noticias y sitios web, por mencionar unos pocos.

Desde la década de 1990 surge una idea muy interesante de aprovechar las opiniones de millones de personas en línea en un esfuerzo por ayudar a todos a encontrar más contenido útil e interesante.

Ha habido una gran cantidad de investigación en los últimos 20 años en ¿cómo? recomendar automáticamente la adquisición o utilización de cosas a la gente.

Una amplia variedad de métodos han sido propuestos en este contexto. Han surgido enfoques algorítmicos para la generación de propuestas de compra personalizadas, tales como filtrado colaborativo y basado en el contenido. Los matemáticos y cientíticos de datos han aportado por décadas algoritmos que modelan estas problemáticas.

Hoy lo nuevo NO SON las matemáticas asociadas a los sistemas de recomendación.

Hoy lo novedoso es que con la Ciencia de Grandes Volúmenes de Datos instrumentando los algoritmos en un ambiente Spark, es factible realizarlo con cluster de equipos accesibles en costo para todos. Y ademas de forma distribuida y tolerante a fallas utilizando lenguajes conocidos ampliamente como Python, R, Scala y Java.

Hoy Spark Machine Learning y Microsoft Azure tiene TODO LISTO para CONSUMIRSE

NO SE LO PIERDAN, NO SE QUEDEN FUERA DE ESTA OPORTUNIDAD DE LAS GRANDES POSIBILIDADES DEL BIGDATA ANALYTICS

Atentamente

Dr. Gabriel GUERRERO

Taller BigData Analytics con Apache Spark de 8 horas de prácticas con un énfasis en Sistemas de Recomendación y Clasificacion utilizando el lenguaje de programación Python

El miércoles 22 de febrero 2017 de 9.30 a 19.00 tendremos nuestro taller BigData Analytics con Spark con programación en Python para modelar Sistemas de Recomendación y Clasificacion!!!

Las prácticas se realizan utilizando Python, con un repaso del lenguaje según lo desee la audiencia

En el taller se ofrece los fundamentos del modelado utilizando los algoritmos matematicos de SVD y ALS.

El taller tiene una CUOTA DE RECUPERACIÓN y se desarrolla  en dos sesiones, la primera de 9.30 a 13.30, con receso de 1.30 hrs para comida y la segunda de 15.00 a 19.00

Nuestro centro de formacion BigData se encuetra a una cuadra de la Glorieta de Insurgentes


Los esperamos de 9.30 a 19.00 para compartirles nuestro gusto por programar en Spark crear aplicaciones de BigData Analytics.

Temario

T1. Big Data en la empresa y aplicaciones con algoritmos matemáticos de la Ciencia de Grandes Volúmenes de Datos (BigData Science)

T2. Uso de herramientas Hadoop HDFS

T3. Apache Spark usando Python con shell PySpark

T4. Apache Spark usando Python para aplicaciones autosuficientes (standalone) con spark-submit

T5. Apache Spark ML (Machine Learning). Analisis principales modelos de la Ciencia de Datos

T6. Algoritmo de clasificación en 2 conjuntos para detección de spam

T7. Sistema de recomendación de películas tipo Netflix con Alternating Least Squares (ALS) y Singular Value Descomposition (SVD).

T8. Uso del JuPytER Notebook en un ambiente Spark

column17: Workshop BigData Analytics 8 horas. Miercoles 22 de febrero CUOTA RECUPERACION

column3:
Taller Streaming Analytics, con CUOTA DE RECUPERACIÓN


BigData en tiempo real con Spark, usando lenguaje Python


viernes 3 de marzo 2017, de 9.30 a 19.00


Workshop de 8 horas de tecleo 

Torrentes de datos con Spark Streaming

Los esperamos numerosos y solo les pedimos una CUOTA DE RECUPERACIÓN

informes: Mtro Rachid GUERRERO cel 55 2825 6572

correo electrónico: info@saxsa.com.mx, saxsa2000@gmail.com, saxsa2000@yahoo.com


Temario

T1. Fundamentos de las herramientas Big Data HDFS, Spark ML y Spark SQL. 


T2. Manejo de torrentes de datos en tiempo real con Spark Streaming.


T3. Análisis de sentimiento de Twitter con Spark Streaming. 


T4. Aplicación de algoritmos de Aprendizaje Automatizado (ML) sobre datos en tiempo real, con Spark ML.

T5. Procesamiento de lenguaje natural con Análisis Semántico Latente LSA . 


T6. Mecanimos de recolección de datos de múltiples productores y múltiples consumidores con Apache Kafka.  

Spark Streaming es módulo Spark que permite el procesamiento de flujo de datos en forma inmediata o en vivo, con característica de poder ser escalable, de alto rendimiento y tolerante a fallas.


Hoy existen aplicaciones que requieren ofrecer resultados de forma instantánea, una vez recibos los datos.


El módulo Spark Streaming permite a los programadores escribir aplicaciones de torrentes de datos (streaming) de forma similar a un programa en lotes, faciliando su uso en aplicaciones que requieren el monitoreo inmediato, por ejemplo la detección de anomalías en sistemas de misión crítica.

En el taller se ofrecen ejemplos programados en el lenguaje Python en el ambiente Apache Spark, para acceder a torrentes de datos de redes sociales, en particular Twitter.

Se ofrece un ejemplo avanzado de uso de algoritmos de Aprendizaje Automatizado (Machine Learning) en torrentes de datos (streaming) para el analisis de sentimiento y otro ejemplo para aplicacion de algoritmos no supervisados de clasificacion de twitter.


También se ofrecen los fundamentos de la plataforma Apache Kafka para la integracion de Productores/Consumidores en una plataforma Apache Spark

Temario

T1. Fundamentos de las herramientas Big Data HDFS, Spark ML y Spark SQL. 


T2. Manejo de torrentes de datos en tiempo real con Spark Streaming.


T3. Análisis de sentimiento de Twitter con Spark Streaming. 


T4. Aplicación de algoritmos de Aprendizaje Automatizado (ML) sobre datos en tiempo real, con Spark ML.


T5. Procesamiento de lenguaje natural con Análisis Semántico Latente LSA . 


T6. Mecanimos de recolección de datos de múltiples productores y múltiples consumidores con Apache Kafka.  


Spark Streaming es módulo Spark que permite el procesamiento de flujo de datos en forma inmediata o en vivo, con característica de poder ser escalable, de alto rendimiento y tolerante a fallas.

Hoy existen aplicaciones que requieren ofrecer resultados de forma instantánea, una vez recibos los datos.

El módulo Spark Streaming permite a los programadores escribir aplicaciones de torrentes de datos (streaming) de forma similar a un programa en lotes, faciliando su uso en aplicaciones que requieren el monitoreo inmediato, por ejemplo la detección de anomalías en sistemas de misión crítica.

En el taller se ofrecen ejemplos programados en el lenguaje Python en el ambiente Apache Spark, para acceder a torrentes de datos de redes sociales, en particular Twitter.

Se ofrece un ejemplo avanzado de uso de algoritmos de Aprendizaje Automatizado (Machine Learning) en torrentes de datos (streaming) para el analisis de sentimiento y otro ejemplo para aplicacion de algoritmos no supervisados de clasificacion de twitter.

También se ofrecen los fundamentos de la plataforma Apache Kafka para la integracion de Productores/Consumidores en una plataforma Apache Spark

Se les ofrece una máquina virtual con todos los sistemas para su instalacion en sus maquinas personales, que se sugiere traer al taller, con procesador al menos Intel I5 con 8 Gb de RAM

¿Qué es?

El Sistema de Archivos Distribuido Hadoop permite el almacenamiento de grandes volúmenes de información en pequeños bloques con mecanismos de replicación y tolerancia a fallas.

Apache Spark, el ambiente de mayor desarrollo en modo clúster de los profesionales de la computación.

¿Por qué?

Dado el gran número de aplicaciones de la Ciencia de datos en procesos comerciales y científicos, la necesidad de contar con desarrolladores de Apache Spark y de sus aplicaciones Big Data cada vez es más frecuente.

¿Qué aprenderás?

Este curso de Apache Spark le enseña los fundamentos para trabajar con el lenguaje Python en modo interactivo y en lotes (batch).

Le proporciona las bases necesarias para la programación y el uso de una arquitectura de cómputo distribuido con Spark y sus bibliotecas, en particular Spark SQL.

Al termino del curso, usted será capaz de escribir y ejecutar aplicaciones básicas en un ambiente Apache Spark en modo pseudo-clúster y en modo clúster.

TEMARIO

Módulo de almacenamiento distribuido y tolerante a fallas

• Introducción al paradigma de Grandes volúmenes de datos (Big Data)

• El almacenamiento con Apache Hadoop con el HDFS (Hadoop Distributed File System)

• Uso de Apache Hadoop: subir y extraer información del HDFS, talla del bloque y factor de replicación, comandos básicos de arranque y finalización de servicios.

• Uso de la Interfaz de Usuario Web (Web UI) de monitoreo de Apache Hadoop HDFS

Módulo de procesamiento distribuido y tolerante a fallas

• Comunicación con Apache Spark desde terminal Linux.

• Levantar y bajar servicios de Apache Spark

• Uso de la Interfaz de Usuario Web (Web UI) de monitoreo de Apache Spark

• Generación de RDD (Resilient Distributed Dataset) por medio

de transformaciones en Spark.

• Ejecución de acciones sobre RRD ́s en el ambiente Spark.

• Utilización del formato de almacenamiento Apache Parquet para el almacenamiento en Hadoop HDFS.

• Inserción de contenido de tipo archivos: texto, json, xml e imágenes.

• Procesamiento de contenido utilizando enunciados SQL por medio del módulo Spark SQL

• Creación de aplicaciones al estilo querys SQL en arquitectura Big Data. Enunciados complejos integrando contenido de fuentes heterogéneas.


A cada participante se les instala una maquina virtual con todos los materiales y sistemas Hadoop y Spark en funcionamiento

Se recomienda traer un equipo al menos INTEL I5 con 8 GB de RAM

¿Por qué los Sistemas de Recomendación?

En esta era de la tecnologías de la información, las personas utilizan una variedad de estrategias para tomar decisiones en aspectos como ¿qué comprar?, ¿cómo pasar su tiempo libre?, e incluso ¿con quiénes hacer amistad como en las redes sociales?.

Los sistemas de recomendación permiten automatizar algunas de estas estrategias de selección con el objetivo de proporcionar recomendaciones asequibles, personales y de alta calidad.

Cada día, estamos inundados de alternativas y opciones. ¿Qué ponerse? ¿Qué película alquilar en los servicios de renta? ¿Qué productos comprar?

Históricamente, las personas se han basado en las recomendaciones y menciones
de sus compañeros o el asesoramiento de expertos, para apoyar las decisiones y descubrir el nuevo artículo o material a adquirir.

Los sistemas interactivos de Internet ofrecen la oportunidad de ampliar el conjunto de personas de donde se pueden obtener datos para construir sistemas de recomendaciones. Cada acción que se realiza en el sistema, genera un registro y estos sistemas nos permitirán conocer la historia de los usuarios y determinar las preferencias por patrones de comportamiento, que ni ellos ni sus conocidos identifican, lo que puede proporcionar una más afinada experiencia de la selección.

La tecnología de los sistemas de recomendación esta ofreciendo soluciones en ámbitos tan diversos como los productos financieros, bienes raíces, productos electrónicos de consumo, películas, libros, música, noticias y sitios web, por mencionar unos pocos.

Desde la década de 1990 surge una idea muy interesante de aprovechar las opiniones de millones de personas en línea en un esfuerzo por ayudar a todos a encontrar más contenido útil e interesante.

Ha habido una gran cantidad de investigación en los últimos 20 años en ¿cómo? recomendar automáticamente la adquisición o utilización de cosas a la gente.

Una amplia variedad de métodos han sido propuestos en este contexto. Han surgido enfoques algorítmicos para la generación de propuestas de compra personalizadas, tales como filtrado colaborativo y basado en el contenido. Los matemáticos y científicos de datos han aportado por décadas algoritmos que modelan estas problemáticas.

Hoy lo nuevo NO SON las matemáticas asociadas a los sistemas de recomendación.

Hoy lo novedoso es que con la Ciencia de Grandes Volúmenes de Datos instrumentando los algoritmos en un ambiente Spark, es factible realizarlo con cluster de equipos accesibles en costo para todos. Y ademas de forma distribuida y tolerante a fallas utilizando lenguajes conocidos ampliamente como Python, R, Scala y Java.

Hoy Spark Machine Learning tiene TODO LISTO para CONSUMIRSE

NO SE LO PIERDAN,  NO SE QUEDEN FUERA DE ESTA OPORTUNIDAD DE LAS GRANDES POSIBILIDADES DEL BIGDATA ANALYTICS

El mecanismo Streaming de Apache Spark


Hoy en dia se cuenta con un modelo de Spark Streaming que soporta aplicaciones de extremo a extremo (end-to-end applications) que reaccionan continuamente a los datos de forma instantánea, es decir en tiempo real.

Estas aplicaciones se denominan aplicaciones continuas que reaccionan a los datos en forma instntanea o tiempo real (continuous applications that react to data in real-time).


En este taller sabatino se ofrecen los fundamentos para la creación de aplicciones continuas con Spark Streaming, incorporando enunciados con Spark SQL

El taller esta planeado para su primera fecha para el jueves 4 de mayo con 8 horas de tecleo, con una CUOTA DE RECUPERACIÓN.

Fundamentos de Ciencia de Datos con Spark

Jueves 4 de mayo con 8 horas de taller.

En este taller se muestra el uso de Apache Spark y sus bibliotecas para realizar un análisis exploratorio de datos (EDA Exploratory Data Analysis), también conocido como Gobernanza de los Datos (Data governance).


Se realizan prácticas con algoritmos de Aprendizaje Automatizado (ML Machine Learning) y realizan aplicaciones con las bibliotecas de DataFrames y ML lib de la Interfaz de Programación de Aplicaciones (API) de Spark.


En el taller se analizan los conceptos que se aplican en los algoritmos paralelizables del Aprendizaje Automatizado que se encuentran en el API ML Spark.


Para llevar a cabo los talleres se utilizan conjuntos de datos abiertos de gran volumen y se muestra como se aplica Apache Spark para desarrollar aplicaciones productivas incorporando mecanismos SQL tradicionales de las bases de datos relacionales, pero en una arquitectura de computo distribuido y tolerante a fallas con la biblioteca Spark SQL.


Se realizan ejemplos utilizando el lenguaje de programación Python y se ofrece un repaso de las principales estructuras que Spark utiliza para la construcción de aplicaciones autosuficientes.


En el despliegue y ambiente interactivo de trabajo se ofrece una plataforma basada en JuPytER, el cuaderno interactivo (I-Notebook) que interactúa directamente al ambiente Spark por medio de la biblioteca Livy server, un servicio de código abierto con protocolo REST para Apache Spark (an Open Source REST Service for Apache Spark)


Pre-requisitos: Tener un poco de experiencia básica en algún lenguaje de programación como Python, R, PHP, Perl o Scala.


En el taller se realiza un repaso básico o introducción al lenguaje Python y su uso en Spark. Un entendimiento básico de la problemática del Aprendizaje Automatizado.


En el taller se realiza una introducción a los conceptos de la Ciencia de Datos en su aspecto Algoritmos del Aprendizaje Automatizado.


Los esperamos numerosos

Dr. Gabriel Guerrero

THIS IS A WEB CONFERENCE ONLY - TIME INDICATED IS LOCAL START TIME. SEE BELOW FOR DETAILS.

IBM InfoSpere Streams V3.2 (referred to as Streams) delivers a highly scalable, agile software infrastructure to perform in-motion analytics on a wide variety of relational and non-relational data types that enter the enterprise at unprecedented volumes and speed, and from thousands of real-time sources. Streams V3.2 includes new features and functions designed to instantly analyze and fuse massive volumes of data and integrates with existing infrastructures. It delivers new capabilities to improve usability, support enterprise readiness, and streamline enterprise integration.

WHAT:

The following new features and functions, which will be covered during the Streams Developer Conference:

Usability:
• Remote Development with Streams Studio for Windows and Linux
• User Defined Parallelism
• Java Streams development simplification

Enterprise readiness:
• Operational Decision Management adapter for business rules
• Access to application data using Representational State Transfer (REST)

Enterprise integration:
• MQTT adapters
• Hadoop Big SQL support
• HP Vertica Analytic Database support

Who should attend:

The event assumes you are familiar with Streams. If you are not, please either try the Big Data University Streams course or review some of the Streams videos on YouTube.

WHEN:

Webcast on Thursday November 14, 2013 from 10:00AM to 6:00PM U.S. Eastern Standard Time.

WHERE:

The webcast will be recorded and posted to Big Data University (BDU) at the following Big Data University course ID.

NOTE: There will be no physical location for this meetup and it will all be online.

To get more info, download presentations, get detailed agenda and to register for the event check out the BDU Streams Developers Virtual Conference landing page.

The detailed agenda will be posted at the BDU class/event page after Oct 31.

Please join us on the live LotusLive meeting webcast. The conference ID is 2058889. Audio in listen only mode will be available on the webcast.

To ask questions during Q&A periods, please use the following conference information:

USA Toll-Free: 1-888-426-6840

USA Caller Paid: 1-215-861-6239

For Other Countries call in numbers use this link.

Participant Code: 7821035

We look forward to sharing details about these new capabilities.
column17: Streams 3.2 Developers Virtual Conference

column3:
Join us and participate in an exclusive Big Data and Analytics Developer Evening hosted by the IBM Big Data and Analytics team.   Open source Apache Hadoop is a great framework for distributed processing of large data sets. But there’s a difference between "playing" with big data versus solving real problems. The reality is that Hadoop alone might not be enough. Experience IBM’s enterprise-class Hadoop product, InfoSphere BigInsights, which enhances open source Hadoop with required enterprise capabilities including: analytics, visualisation, security, standard SQL, enterprise HBase, developer/admin tools.

We will kick off with Big Data use case discussions and an overview of what big data really is, and then move quickly to get hands-on with Big Data using InfoSphere BigInsights Quick Start Edition with guidance from development experts. This is a unique opportunity to develop skills and learn about exciting technologies and techniques that you can immediately take back to your organisation.

This event is FREE. Drinks and some food will be provided.

Agenda (subject to change) 
6.30pm to 7pm Arrivals & Registration

7pm to 7.15pm Welcome and Keynote - Big Data Overview

7.15pm to 7.30pm Big Data @ Rest (Hadoop)

7.30pm to 9pm Hands-on Lab - tentative labs

            • Lever the full power of SQL with Hadoop

Labs will use BigInsights Quick Start VM.  To learn more beforehand and get hands on go to Big Data University.  By downloading the IBM BigInsights Quick Start Edition VM in advance, participants will have the chance to get hands on with IBM's enterprise-class Hadoop distribution. A facilitated lab exercise will walk through the process of generating and loading data and then creating the necessary structures to query it using IBM's full ANSI standard SQL interface. This will demonstrate some of the power and flexibility of IBM's platform.

9pm Close and Thank You for Attending 

Seating is limited, please adjust your RSVP accordingly.

Registration is required.  This event is limited to only 60 seated and 40 standing. You may let others know that you are going to this event by clicking on the YES RSVP button on this Meetup page—however— your seat can not be guaranteed until you officially register at the link above.

Thanks and we look forward to seeing you soon!
column17: Inaugural Big Data and Analytics Developer Meetup

Based on feedback from our members, we're going to focus in on real-time streaming technology as well as discuss the latest opportunities to collaborate with the cognitive analytics system called Watson.  We also want to include a war stories round-table, so if you have a story you want to share, let the organisers know through a private email and we'll sort out how to give you your moment of fame to share with the group.

We can now confirm that we will be at Birkbeck, University of London from 630pm-9pm on June 11th . Room MAL541.

Places are limited so we will be operating on a first-come, first-served basis - make sure to arrive on time so that you don't miss out on a place in the room!


We'll be posting a full agenda up at the end of today. In the meantime here's a link to the Streams technology we will be sampling on the day. If you are able to download this ready for the event, that would be great!

http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/downloads/im/streamsquick/


Looking foward to seeing you there!

-The team

column3:
Following successful meetups in Silicon Valley, New York and Toronto, IBM is pleased to come to London and discuss the latest on SQL on Hadoop.

We will discuss the various SQL on Hadoop alternatives and explore why such technologies have become an area of keen interest for many organizations.  We will discuss the various alternatives (Drill, Impala, Hive, Hadapt, Tajo, Shark, HAWQ, Presto, Phoenix, Big SQL) and their pros/cons.  We will share customer use cases for Warehouse Modernization and the role of SQL for Hadoop in this space, as well as discuss performance characteristics of SQL on Hadoop when running common query workloads. 

We will provide an intro to Big SQL and demo.   Big SQL  delivers some exciting capabilities including comprehensive SQL functionality that leverages advanced SQL compiler/runtime all with low latency and high performance.

Learn more about Big SQL here.   Check out new SQL on Hadoop white paper.

In order to satisfy some security requirements for this IBM location, please answer the questions in the RSVP application.
column17: A Leap Forward for SQL on Hadoop

CALLING ALL DEVELOPERS .... JOIN THE BIG DATA FOR SOCIAL GOOD CHALLENGE

Big data exists in just about everything we use and do. It comes from phones, cars, roads, power lines, waterways, food crates, and innumerable other items you’d never think of as computers. This data speaks volumes about our collective behavior and society – so let’s use it to do something incredible! IBM invites developers and data enthusiasts to take a deep dive into real world civic issues using big data and the IBM Bluemix Analytics for Hadoop service. Analyze one of our curated datasets or bring your own (provided it meets these requirements)! Use Hadoop and your data to create a clickable and interactive data visualization to highlight insights that you’ve found.

Ready to get started? $40,000 in prizes will be awarded....

Register here:http://ibmhadoop.challengepost.com/

What to Create: Participants must create a working, clickable, and interactive data visualization utilizing the Analytics for Hadoop service on IBM Bluemix.

Data Requirements: Your data visualization must analyze one or more datasets included in the curated list of datasets on the Data page OR meet the data size, content, and licensing requirements described on the Data page. The total size of the Datasets analyzed must be between 500MB - 7GB in size.

Check out the requirements then go get your IBM Bluemix extended promo code and check out the datasets!

column3:
This is a joint meetup with SkillsMatter and Cake Solutions.  To register you need to join (for Free) SkillsMatter here, please also RSVP here so we know how many of our group will be going.

Are you interested in getting to grips with machine learning, and how it can be used to create an Internet of Things system with IBM SystemML and Apache Spark? 

Nikolay Manchev (Big Data Technical Specialist, IBM Analytics) will cover IBM's commitment to Spark, how IBM SystemML can help advance machine learning, how to roll out machine learning algorithms in production and how to achieve shorter development times and increased algorithm performance

Jan Machacek (Cake Solutions) will explore the latest developments of the MUVR project. After a brief introduction on the nature of distributed systems (from distributed databases, through distributed state, to distributed computation), you will learn how to use Akka Cluster and Akka Persistence to implement such distributed systems. Once the data is safely stored in a journal, it is important to be able to perform deeper analysis. To do so, Jan will show you how to access the data in the journal in a distributed computation program running in Apache Spark.

With the mechanics done, Jan will explain how to use (deep) neural networks that can be very easily trained to recognize patterns in the ingested data.

You will learn the advantages and traps of designing distributed domains, data and computation: systems that may become the next generation of financial systems, bringing elasticity, resilience and responsiveness. You will look in particular at systems that consume data from IoT / wearables, and that perform immediate and batch analyses.

Registration from 6pm, talks begin at 6:30pm.  As always this is followed with the opportunity to network with the speakers and your peers.
column13: To reach CodeNode from Moorgate Station, exit Moorgate station, turn right onto Moorgate, turn right again onto South Place. Walk down on South Place until you reach number 10 on your right.
column17: Machine Learning, Deep Learning, SystemML & Apache Spark

column3:
To kick off the year (yes, I know it is March), I thought it would be good to listen to a number of successful data science projects created for large enterprises in the UK. We may not be able to mention all companies by name....but we can explain the data challenge and the solution devised.

7pm to 7:45pm
How the London Data Science Studio delivers transformative insights to business decision-makers

Members of IBM's London Data Science studio will describe recent projects delivering behaviour based customer insight and Lift Analytics solutions as well as specific projects run for Financial Services and Distribution sector clients. Lift Analytics helps retail clients make better product, pricing and placement decisions and are part of IBM's Industry Analytics Solutions. These are pre-built predictive analytics, data preparation and user dashboards enabling clients to get started and go faster, using fewer resources, by using our pre-built expertise.

London Data Science Studio's mission is to design, build & help implement differentiated, advanced analytics solutions for IBM clients in a wide variety of industries. The Data Science Studios are a client collaboration hub to apply IBM advanced analytics solutions, and rapidly demonstrate value to our clients. The studios also serve as an intellectual hub for data science solutions – uniting clients, analytics Subject Matter Experts (SMEs), researchers, academics from the area and analytics experts from industry.

7:45pm to 8:30pm
Simple Search Service with Cloudant


NoSQL allows scalability and schema-flexibility but it can be hard to make the leap from a relational database to a NoSQL solution. This demonstration shows how to move data from CSV files into a NoSQL database and make it searchable using free, open-source software. This enables you to implement a powerful search engine within your app or website and is much easier than you think.


8:30 onwards - networking
column17: A Melee of Data Science projects

column3:
I am really pleased to announce that this MeetUp will now meet regularly on the fourth Thursday of every month at CodeNode.  CodeNode is the UK's largest venue dedicated to technology events in the heart of London.  

To register you need to join (for Free) SkillsMatter here, please also RSVP on this site so we know how many of our group will be going (otherwise I will not have enough beer tokens!).

For our first month we will be looking at the power of cognitive computing for Data Scientists.

IBM Watson is a technology platform that uses natural language processing and machine learning to reveal insights from large amounts of unstructured data. In this talk, Olly Cox and James Ravenscroft will demonstrate the power of some of the Watson APIs with example code and usage patterns for chaining these services together in order to create powerful text processing pipelines.  The IBM Watson APIs can be trialled for free to add cognitive capabilities to data science projects, so you can immediately experiment with these APIs following this session.

Olly Cox and James Ravenscroft are Solutions Architects from IBM's Watson division. Olly's experience as veteran developer and technologist at a Business Intelligence company and James' data science background and part time PhD studies in Natural Language Processing, enable them to spend their days thinking of innovative ways to integrate Watson's machine learning and text analysis capabilities into a wide variety of use cases across a number of industries.

Outline agenda
 - Watson Introduction + general overview
 - Discussion and demonstration of interactive Watson use cases i.e. dialoguing and conversations
 - Data discovery and enrichment demo (with code)
 - Q&A followed by networking

I am looking for volunteers and topic suggestions for future meetings, not necessarily using IBM technology.  Hot topics such as Spark, Real-time data processing (Streams/Storm), Machine Learning and Predictive Analytics.  So please contact me if you have a story to tell.


See you there!
column17: IBM Watson - It's for data scientists too!

column3:
I am really pleased to announce the second of our new monthly MeetUps at CodeNode,  the UK's largest venue dedicated to technology events in the heart of London.  

To register you need to join (for Free) SkillsMatter here, please also RSVP on this site so we know how many of our group will be going (otherwise I will not have enough beer tokens!)

This month we will cover two hot topics in the area of Big Data Analytics. There is a lot of confusion over Machine Learning and we aim to solve that by running a number of introductory sessions about this technology, suitable for beginners, this is the first of that series. The second session then focuses on the real-time analysis of data produced by sensors and introduces Quarks as a new approach using open-source technology.


Introduction to Machine Learning – Linear Regression and Gradient Descent

This will be the first of a series of introductory Machine Learning lectures suitable for beginners. In the first module we will define what Machine Learning is, we will look at various resources you can use to expand your knowledge on the contents of the series, and we will drill down into Linear Regression models.

We will focus on parameter estimation using Gradient Descent and Normal Equations and we will see these methods in action using a simple dataset. The language of choice for this Machine Learning series is Python, so if you are not familiar with Python or if you need to brush up your skills we suggest you spend some time with the videos from the freely available Google's Python Class.

Our speaker, Nikolay Manchev has over 10 years of database experience and has been involved in large scale migration, consolidation, and data warehouse deployment projects in the UK and abroad.


Obtaining fast analytics from the Internet of Things

This session will demonstrate how to use Streams and Quarks to get rapid insight from data in motion. Quarks are a breakthrough technology now available to the open source community that embeds streaming analytics onto Internet of Things (IoT) devices. Analysing data at the edge continuously, can help companies generate insights more quickly and reduce network communication costs.


Developers and data scientists can use the open source code in Quarks to build new apps that can handle massive amounts of IoT data streaming from sensors, smart meters, mobile communications and other connected devices. This is an incredibly exciting area for all Big Data practitioners.

Jerome Chailloux has been involved in streaming data analysis for over 7 years specialising in gaining insights from data produced by sensors. He is closely involved in the Connected Cars project and also aiding Supermarkets to understand customer buying behaviour in store.

As always these sessions will be followed by networking in the bar area.
column17: Double bill: Machine Learning and Quarks

column3:
THIS MEETUP AND LIVE STREAMING IS US PACIFIC STANDARD TIME (PST). PLEASE CONVERT TO YOUR TIME ZONE.

On June 6, 2016, leading minds in data and analytics from Tesla, Netflix, Silicon Valley Data Science, and IBM will come together to demonstrate how open data and analytics technologies such as R, Spark, Python and more are forming a vibrant ecosystem.  The community has a shared goal of working with all data to build unexpected insights and launch new business applications.

The Apache Spark Maker Community Event will bring together data scientists, data engineers, data developers, and data designers June 6th @ 6pm at Galvanize, San Francisco. Here’s the plan:   

- The Big Reveal – New sample Apache Spark apps and tools

- Use Cases – Monsanto will share how they are using R and Spark to optimize their supply chain

- Learning Session - Hear from experts working on Spark projects and building the Spark ecosystem of open data and analytics technologies

- Networking Opportunity – Food, drinks and data, explore a Hall of Innovation showcasing Spark demos
